baseline_anchor.note: Using H1 2025 as proxy for FY2024 given strategic pivot timing

M1_revenue_growth.description: Revenue evolution driven by (1) CPaaS volume growth offset by margin erosion, (2) Zenvia Customer Cloud SaaS scaling, (3) CPaaS divestiture impact
M1_revenue_growth.rationale: 2025: BRL 1,040MM baseline (H1 run-rate). Assumes CPaaS continues at ~BRL 840MM (declining margins but stable volume), SaaS reaches BRL 200MM. 2026-2027: CPaaS divestiture executes (50% probability by 2027), removing BRL 400-500MM revenue. Post-divestiture: SaaS-only business targeting BRL 350-400MM by 2029 (25% CAGR from 2025 BRL 200MM base). Path: 2025 BRL 1,040MM → 2026 BRL 980MM (CPaaS margin pressure) → 2027 BRL 550MM (CPaaS sold mid-year) → 2028 BRL 380MM (SaaS ramping) → 2029 BRL 350MM (SaaS maturation).
key_assumptions: CPaaS revenue stable in volume but margin continues eroding 2025-2026
CPaaS divestiture executes mid-2027 at BRL 450MM valuation (~1.0x revenue)
Zenvia Customer Cloud grows 25-30% annually 2025-2029
Franchisee channel contributes 20-25% of SaaS new bookings by 2027
Post-divestiture focus accelerates SaaS growth to 30% CAGR 2028-2029
risks: CPaaS divestiture fails to execute or achieves <0.7x revenue
SaaS scaling slower than plan (15-20% vs 25-30% growth)
Competitive pressure in Brazil CX market intensifies

M2_margin_evolution.description: Gross margin trajectory driven by business mix shift from low-margin CPaaS to high-margin SaaS
M2_margin_evolution.rationale: 2025: 22% blended (CPaaS 12-15%, SaaS 55%). 2026: 23% (slight improvement as SaaS grows). 2027: 45% (CPaaS exit mid-year). 2028-2029: 65-68% (SaaS-only, approaching 70% target with scale). Path reflects mix shift from 72% CPaaS to 100% SaaS.
key_assumptions: CPaaS margin stabilizes at 15% by Q4 2025 (from Q2 12% trough)
SaaS margin improves from 55% to 68-70% with scale and operational leverage
Post-divestiture, G&A reallocated to support SaaS growth but at lower % of revenue
R&D efficiency improves as platform matures
risks: CPaaS margin remains <15% if competitive pressure persists
SaaS margin expansion slower due to customer acquisition costs
Price competition in Brazil SaaS market limits pricing power

M3_operating_leverage.description: EBITDA margin evolution reflecting cost discipline, mix shift, and scale benefits
M3_operating_leverage.rationale: 2025: 9% EBITDA margin (BRL ~95MM EBITDA on BRL 1,040MM revenue). 2026: 8% (margin pressure pre-divestiture). 2027: 12% (one-time costs from transition). 2028-2029: 25-28% (SaaS-only model with 68% gross margin and G&A at 15-18% of revenue). Reflects path from subscale mixed model to focused SaaS platform.
key_assumptions: G&A remains disciplined at BRL 100-120MM absolute through 2027
Post-divestiture G&A scales to 15-18% of SaaS revenue (vs current 8% of blended)
R&D investment increases to 12-15% of SaaS revenue (vs current 7%)
Sales & Marketing scales to 20-25% of SaaS revenue to drive growth
risks: SaaS customer acquisition costs higher than expected
G&A cannot scale down proportionally post-CPaaS exit
Competitive dynamics require elevated marketing spend

M4_working_capital.description: Working capital as % of revenue, improving from current negative position
M4_working_capital.rationale: Current negative working capital of BRL -444MM driven by acquisition liabilities and stretched payables. Post-CPaaS divestiture and debt paydown, working capital normalizes to slight negative (industry norm for SaaS with prepaid subscriptions). Assumes proceeds used to clear acquisition liabilities and refinance debt.
key_assumptions: CPaaS sale proceeds clear BRL 271MM acquisition liabilities
Remaining proceeds reduce net debt from BRL 60MM to zero
SaaS business operates at -5% working capital (deferred revenue model)
risks: Divestiture fails; working capital crisis forces distressed financing
Customer payment terms deteriorate in competitive environment

M5_capex.description: Capital expenditures for platform development and infrastructure
M5_capex.rationale: CapEx historically BRL 35-40MM annually (data processing equipment, software development). As % of revenue: ~3-4% on BRL 1,040MM base. SaaS-only model requires higher platform investment: targeting 8-10% of SaaS revenue for AI/automation features, integrations, and infrastructure. Absolute CapEx stable at BRL 28-35MM but higher % of smaller SaaS revenue base.
key_assumptions: Platform investment required to compete in AI-driven CX market
Cloud infrastructure scales efficiently with usage
No major M&A or new product line CapEx
risks: Technology refresh cycles accelerate with AI competition
Customer feature demands require elevated R&D CapEx

M6_tax_rate.rationale: Current effective rate near zero due to accumulated tax losses (BRL 85MM deferred tax assets as of June 2025). Tax loss carryforwards shield ~BRL 250MM of future taxable income. 2025-2027: minimal cash taxes. 2028-2029: 10-15% effective rate as losses utilized and profitability returns. Brazilian statutory rate 34% (IRPJ + CSLL).
key_assumptions: Tax loss carryforwards fully utilized by 2029
No significant change in Brazilian corporate tax regime
SaaS revenues primarily Brazil-sourced

M7_special_items.description: CPaaS divestiture proceeds and one-time restructuring costs

schedule.note: Restructuring costs for CPaaS separation and executive departures
CPaaS sale proceeds BRL 450MM (1.0x revenue) net of BRL 15MM transaction costs

M7_special_items.rationale: Central case assumes CPaaS divestiture executes mid-2027 at BRL 450MM (1.0x BRL 420MM annualized revenue). Proceeds used to: (1) clear BRL 271MM acquisition liabilities, (2) repay BRL 60MM net debt, (3) fund BRL 50-80MM SaaS growth investments, (4) BRL 40-70MM cash buffer. One-time costs: 2026 restructuring BRL 15MM (severance, separation), 2027 transaction costs BRL 15MM (advisors, legal).
key_assumptions: CPaaS buyer found at 0.8-1.2x revenue valuation
Transaction closes mid-2027 (18-month process from Dec 2025 announcement)
No tax leakage on sale proceeds
risks: Valuation <0.7x revenue due to market deterioration
Proceeds insufficient to clear all acquisition liabilities

strategic_scenarios.label: Successful Pivot
strategic_scenarios.description: CPaaS divests mid-2027 at BRL 450MM, proceeds fund SaaS scaling to BRL 350MM by 2029 at 68% gross margin and 28% EBITDA margin
strategic_scenarios.note: Central case reflected in M-slots above

strategic_scenarios.label: SaaS Breakout
strategic_scenarios.description: CPaaS divests early 2027 at 1.2x revenue (BRL 540MM). SaaS accelerates to 35% CAGR on AI differentiation, reaches BRL 450MM by 2029 at 70% gross margin and 32% EBITDA margin
strategic_scenarios.note: Requires exceptional SaaS execution and favorable CPaaS M&A market

strategic_scenarios.label: Stranded Asset
strategic_scenarios.description: CPaaS divestiture fails or achieves <0.7x revenue (BRL 280-320MM). Liquidity crisis forces dilutive equity raise or distressed asset sales. SaaS grows slowly (15% CAGR) to BRL 250MM by 2029 at 60% gross margin and 18% EBITDA margin
strategic_scenarios.note: Downside case if strategic pivot stumbles

gestalt_summary.narrative: Zenvia is attempting a high-risk strategic pivot from a commoditized, mixed CPaaS/SaaS model to a pure-play SaaS business. The investment case hinges on two binary outcomes: (1) successful CPaaS divestiture at reasonable valuation to repair the balance sheet, and (2) Zenvia Customer Cloud achieving scale and profitability to justify a SaaS-like valuation multiple. Current financials reflect a company trapped between two business models—CPaaS margin erosion drags down consolidated profitability despite SaaS progress. The GIM models a successful pivot: revenue declines from BRL 1,040MM (2025) to BRL 350MM (2029) as low-margin CPaaS exits, but margins expand dramatically (22% → 68% gross, 9% → 28% EBITDA) as the SaaS mix reaches 100%. The BRL 435MM net proceeds from CPaaS sale (2027) are the critical inflection point, eliminating liquidity stress and funding SaaS growth. Failure to execute this pivot results in a bear case of continued margin compression, cash burn, and eventual distressed restructuring.
key_value_drivers: CPaaS divestiture execution and valuation (0.8-1.2x revenue)
Zenvia Customer Cloud scaling velocity (20-35% CAGR)
G&A discipline post-divestiture (15-18% of SaaS revenue)
major_uncertainties: CPaaS M&A market conditions and buyer appetite
Competitive dynamics in Brazil CX/SaaS market
Management execution risk amid organizational churn
